The vistas of the African safari are stunning.
The most likely of Disneynature's three films to actually enthrall and captivate younger children.
Do you love the death penality and hate lawyers? Then don't miss this movie.
Sanders inspires joy in life's redemption and anger towards the ludicrous ways some states treat the exonerated.
Directed with compassion and outrage.
A powerfully affecting documentary on the subject of wrongful convictions overturned by DNA evidence.
An evenhanded but nonetheless startling depiction of a system that isn't merely blind -- it's deaf, dumb and stupid, as well.
A compelling look at a flawed system.
An extraordinary documentary about injustices rectified and innocent men set free after years in prison.
After Innocence doesn't inspire much confidence in the American legal system.
Evokes the quote, 'A liberal is a conservative that's been arrested.'
Both riveting and disturbing.
Calm, deliberate and devastating, Jessica Sanders's documentary confirms many of the worst fears about weaknesses in the American criminal-justice system.
The film cuts away from such personal stories too quickly, eager to sell us on airy, unjustified claims.
A powerful indictment of a judicial system too anxious to close cases, and then close ranks when someone tries to reopen them.

The film avoids being just a promo piece for the Project by focusing on the former prisoners' poignant personal stories, which include rebuilding their lives, campaigns against the death penalty and getting compensation for law enforcement's mistakes.
Taylor does her cause no real favors by trotting out only the most articulate, most clearly railroaded exonerees.
The moral purity of After Innocence is so overwhelming that it simply leaves you with nothing to say or do. It's kind of beyond criticism.
In her clear and compelling film, Sanders lets the innocents do the talking.
the grotty details of the political and legal muck miring the entire process are nowhere to be found
Sanders' report from a new frontier in American jurisprudence is filled with the hopeful, haunted look of men who won't easily be forgotten.
Even-handed but quietly devastating.
[A] rousing, quietly outraged documentary.
While the film is rich in fascinating, factual information, the most remarkable aspect of After Innocence is its unfailing humanity.

A strikingly varied collection of individual stories with a chilling common thread: the ease with which the criminal justice system can and does fail law-abiding, innocent Americans each and every day.
...the type of work that should inspire social reform
Come Oscar night, After Innocence will almost certainly trump them all. It's not necessarily better than any of the others, but its call for social awareness rings out bolder and rises higher.
Deeply touching and overwhelmingly sad.
[Documaker] Jennifer Sanders builds a solid foundation in making the point that, sometimes, our system of justice does the wrong thing, no matter how well meaning.
Each lost face in the documentary is a burning reminder of the human toll when our justice system succumbs to its imperfections.
Sanders is more interested in specific human struggles than in larger political points, but she knows these men form a mosaic with a message that's unmistakable.
The embittered men make fascinating subjects. Although innocent, they have been deeply scarred by their prison years.
Informative (we learn, for example, that exonerees are generally given no follow-up assistance upon release, as parolees are) and deeply moving.
Not a special pleader but is fairly special, because Sanders gives it the pressure of straight moral conviction.
Sanders has an important message, unfortunately diluted by unimaginative shooting and insufficient editing.
...terrific agitprop journalism/analysis...
This is no-frills filmmaking and may be a little talky, but it's also very well-made, powerful stuff, and it should be seen by anyone who has questions about the American justice system.
After Innocence is, without making it overly obvious, anti-death penalty on the grounds that a just society cannot afford to make any mistakes that we cannot attempt to rectify.
[The] stories of injustice and perseverence [will] stick in the memory after watching this uncluttered and compelling film.
Despite its flaws After Innocence raises staggering questions about virtually every aspect of the criminal-justice system.
You'll probably like it and wish it were better.
Eye-opening.
After Innocence is a crusading documentary driven by DNA testing that's brought freedom for men who served years in prison for crimes they didn't commit.

The scope of the problem, with likely thousands of innocent people incarcerated thanks mostly to errant eyewitness testimony, should give pause to anyone who thinks that life is as simple as black and white, innocent and guilty.
A rough but engrossing sketch of what freedom feels like, and what it costs, for seven men who've endured that national nightmare.
Both sorrowful and uplifting.
Documentary shines a scientific spotlight on the criminal justice system's dirty little secret via ten tragic cases of mistaken identity, each an unfortunate rush to judgment.
An advertorial rather than a solid piece of investigative journalism.
Powerful docu on post-prison lives of falsely accused.
The subject matter and content is so moving and thought-provoking that it hardly matters if the movie is a technical achievement.
a handsomely produced film that doesn't explore new territory or forge ahead with new insight, but is useful, nonetheless, as a primer on the history of the period
"Lesbians! We're everywhere! Lesbiana! Yo soy lesbiana!"
All the same, broken as it is, it still just about functions as a gentle, well-meaning reminder to be thankful for what you've got, rather than fearful at the prospect of losing it.
An out-of-work insurance man makes ends meet by turning to armed robbery in this overwrought and preposterous recession-era morality play from editor turned director Saar Klein.
Beautifully shot but disappointingly slack, Things People Do is ultimately as dull and forgettable as its title.
Moral ambiguity is center stage, and the film ultimately succeeds by sending audiences home to ponder their own levels of sin.
[The film] has much to recommend, including gorgeous New Mexico landscapes, sumptuous digital cinematography and -- as we might expect from Klein -- virtuoso editing.
Scanlon's desperate dive into a life of armed robbery is simply not believable, despite Bentley's best efforts.
If you can avoid dwelling on its derivative qualities, "After the Fall" has its own case to make about how far the middle class has fallen - and continues to slide.
"After the Fall" belongs to a type of movie that is too lazy to connect the dots and fill in the blanks between its supposedly teachable moments.
A substandard "crime drama" that reeks of the Idiot Plot Syndrome.
A film that could only succeed by sorting through gradually darkening shades of gray works exclusively in embarrassingly bold strokes.
Fall isn't going to cure the world's ills, but it does define a few of them to satisfaction, creating an engrossing journey into extremity without ringing all the obvious bells on the way down.
The basic story's narrative and psychological simplicity - characters stating their beliefs over and over again - becomes an increasing burden.
Forgettable...Bentley is bland, first scene to last, and thanks to its subject, the film is instantly dated
There are hints along the way of the socioeconomic strife that Klein wants to explore, yet they become lost in a muddled screenplay that doesn't establish sympathy for its protagonist or his plight.
Filled with convenient turns and easily attainable avenues of retribution, the film ultimately seems like an archaic example of the dangerous follies of patriarchy.
They're not heroes and they're not demons. After Tiller is an important reminder of the personal stories of doctors and mothers that can get lost in an issue as divisive as abortion.
"No body wants a fucking abortion" exclaims one of the doctors, and this is at the heart of the tough decisions that are played out every day within each clinic

After Tiller is not an important film just because of its political and cultural relevance, but because of its humane and compassionate approach to telling the stories of these doctors, their work and the women that they seek to help.
The directors are smart enough to understand that no matter how strongly you believe in a position, that belief is probably more shaded than a one-word "Yes" or "No."
A down-to-earth, non-sensational look at the only four doctors in the U.S. who perform third trimester abortions
A sensitive and intelligent documentary about the compassion and heroism of four doctors.
It gives a true sense of how the forces of a hypocritically religious country has burdened countless young women with a lifetime of misplaced guilt.
Hard-nosed advocacy segues into lefty-evangelizing treacle as a cloying score accompanies a number of dewy scenes better suited to a maudlin Oprah Winfrey special.
The film is warm and scrupulous, like a sunny women's clinic.
"After Tiller" is impressive because it honestly presents the views of supporters of legal abortion, and is thus a valuable contribution to a public argument that is unlikely to end anytime soon.
Empathetic, intimate look inside late-term abortion clinics that focuses on the experiences of doctors and their patients.
Like the men and women it follows, who do the work that few others dare, 'After Tiller' takes a stand.

After Tiller's...true value comes from going inside these clinics, listening to the stories...and asking viewers to wrestle with the moral and ethical complexities of an issue that absolutists on both sides oversimplify.
After Tiller is an hour and a half of folks on their best behavior, presented as a candid portrait.
No matter which side of the abortion issue you're on, prepare to be emotionally devastated.
Addressing an issue many Americans are uncomfortable with, this informative documentary sheds light and humanity on reproductive rights in this country.
After Tiller's greatest failing is the way in which is fails to engage at length how entrenched the stalemate on abortion is.
"After Tiller" takes the politically divisive, emotionally charged issue of late-term abortions and portrays it with grace, understatement and humanity.
"After Tiller" is groundbreaking in giving voice not only to the doctors, but to those who always seem to get overlooked in the high-volume political debate about this topic: the women themselves.
"Its unflinching portrayal of what can only be called battle fatigue is indelible.
A surprisingly warm abortion documentary that restores the human element to an irreducibly human dilemma.
It's an in-the-trenches exploration of bravery.
The film is a welcome exploration of practical and philosophical matters seldom broached across the partisan divide.
After Tiller gives a human and compassionate face to a complex and touchy issue.
After Tiller takes a compassionate look at a highly impassioned situation.
It's humanizing and heartbreaking.
Wrenching yet illuminating. The film reveals the complex circumstances, emotions and practical aspects behind the (third-trimester abortion) procedure.
A documentary that may infuriate those who find what these doctors do unconscionable, but that provides a rare forum for these dedicated, complex professionals to have their say.
The movie takes a calm and intellectual approach to an inflammatory subject, elevating what could have easily come off as propaganda into a reasoned and thoughtful work of journalism.
Compelling, revealing [its] subjects as sympathetic human beings simply by observing and talking to them about their work and their lives.

This is not a balanced doc -- of the little time given to the anti-abortion movement, most of it is from news footage -- but it is an important look at the lives of those who risk their own lives to perform what they see as a necessary service.
After Tiller movingly dramatizes another side effect of the job: how difficult it can be for the doctors to not internalize the sadness of the women who walk through their doors.
What makes this well-edited film compelling are the stories of the patients and the agonizing moral quandaries that the doctors express in doing their work.

It's a calm, thoughtful film about an incendiary subject, and it has a clear point of view: to allow these doctors (and some of their patients, who we hear but don't see) to explain why they do what they do.
Simultaneously tough and compassionate, it's a fine addition to the debate.
This wrenching documentary, profiling the four doctors who still provide third-trimester abortions in the U.S., is remarkable for being so level-headed.
Wrenching portrait of life and death decisions where even the definition of "life" is emotionally laden for doctors and pregnant women considering abortion.

"After Tiller" does viewers the great service of providing light where there's usually only heat, giving a human face and heart to what previously might have been an abstract issue or quickly scanned news item.
Moving, thought-provoking documentary.
If After Tiller does not feel grim, despite the overwhelming presence in it of death and mourning, that's perhaps because it is so much a film about intimacy and trust.
You may or may not be convinced, but you will be affected.

This is one of the best films I've seen this year. The access to doctors, their staffs, patients and families is very impressive. It has a lot of emotional power and it plays the abortion issue right down the middle.
Its strength lies in its ability to coax out the personalities behind the arguments, and to show us that, at the heart of every such controversy, there are vulnerable human beings.
We can see how they wrestle and it's immeasurably moving because they've given it endless consideration and still put themselves in harm's way.
Rarely is this issue presented so fairly and without the requisite hysteria.
It's a grim story.
A laudably even-handed examination of a highly charged subject.
The story of four women and their attempts to uphold abortion rights in the US makes for compelling, if horrifying viewing.
Directors Martha Shane and Lana Wilson in this topical documentary ably tackle in a fair-minded and detailed way the controversial issue of third-trimester abortions.
The film goes about its grave task with compassion, basic professionalism, and discretion.

This documentary portrait of abortion doctors in America, particularly those who perform late-term abortions, looks at those who do important, compassionate work, but isn't as engaging as it should be.
More than simply informative (which it most certainly is), After Tiller is a reminder that seeing eye-to-eye is rarely as impossible as we might think.
Engaging and thoughtful, After Tiller's examination of its main subjects forms a documentary that wisely treats its subject with more curiosity than dogma.

The film succeeds, however, because it manages to rise above the controversy surrounding legalized abortion in America and objectively presents what's at stake here for the doctors and women involved.
I understand that "After Tiller" is intended to be a pro-choice film and have no problem with that. It would be a stronger one if it took the other side more seriously.
You may not leave the theater with a different view, but that's not the point. A good film is one that starts a conversation and provokes thought, and After Tiller is certainly one of those films.
There is nothing easy about After Tiller. Not the watching or the telling.

After Tiller is undoubtedly at its most compelling when stripped down to doctor-patient level. The majority of the testimonies from those individuals wishing to be considered for the third-trimester process are truly heartbreaking.
An essential piece of media for understanding the issue.
After Tiller is, to put it simply, a surprisingly boring documentary considering how sensitive of a topic abortion is.
This portrayal of [the doctors'] work, dedication, and grace under pressure is heart-breaking in so many ways.
[L]ooks at those who do important, compassionate work, but isn't as engaging as it should be.
Two sequels are planned, God help us.
This film's shoestring budget is just far too apparent, making it impossible to take seriously. But it has its moments.
Bean and Danny Dyer butt heads in an engaging manner, and the icy locations add an atmospheric backdrop.
The gruelling training, clandestine mission and sacrifice is familiar Boy's Own stuff but the lack of a decent budget really hurts the film.

Dyer has forged a career around screen violence which can leave a very unpleasant aftertaste. But this is a relatively conventional Second World War story about seizing Nazi radar technology from occupied Norway and he's all the better for it.
The film is a good start, but such an important artist deserves a more rigorous portrait.
Doc about dissident artist is long on political friction, short on art.
Let's hope Klayman gets to make a sequel.
A necessary, compelling and very funny introduction to the eponymous artist as well as a good point of access for Americans who know little of China's creative activists.
Alison Klayman's documentary briskly tells his story, much of it recorded by Ai in his own documentaries, on his Web site, and on his Twitter feed.
Alison Klayman has a fascinating subject for her first feature -- the media savvy Chinese activist artist who lays his career, family and life on the line for civil rights.
The director's clear-minded approach allows her subject's more challenging aesthetic-political mix to shine through, even if it's at the inevitable expense of her own filmmaking proclivities.
His spiritedness makes the darker places his story goes all the more affectingly tragic.
He radiates a mischievous sense of the absurdity - and necessity - of one man tossing stones at a regime this gigantic.
A useful primer, though it also focuses a bit more on the activism than on the art.

He may still seem enigmatic, but we don't need to know his deepest thoughts. The intensity of his daily life and the persecution he continues to face is more than enough to understand who he is and what he is enduring.
Klayman had full access to Ai, 55, following him around for two years. The sweetest footage involves Ai and his mother.
Ai Weiwei is too commanding and fascinating a figure to ignore, and Never Sorry is an excellent showcase for why he matters to the world.
Ai Weiwei is a crucial figure of East-West cultural communication and contemporary history, whose middle finger extended at the centers of power stands for a rising tide of global discontent.
The fluidity and convenience of digital moviemaking tools explain some of its freshness, as does Ms. Klayman's history as a budding documentarian.
The film's greatest distinction is its intimacy.
One can't help wishing the subject would make his own, more complex cinematic self-portrait. But for now, Klayman has provided a valuable introduction to a man everyone should know.
Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry accomplishes what the best works of this sort do: Take a great, compelling, widely known story and make it deeper, fuller and better.
Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry is a portrait of a brave (or simply stubborn) eccentric in action.
A compelling documentary about the Chinese contemporary artist who seems to spend his life on a blade's edge, dancing on a knife that's in the hands of the government.
Klayman acquaints us with the man behind the decisions, an extraordinarily down-to-earth yet cosmopolitan figure, full of mischief, courage and defiance.
Offers a good introduction to the career of this fascinating man who is no shrinking violet.

Terrific documentary about the recent headline-grabbing dissident Chinese artist-activist is a provocative portrait of an amusing, even self-deprecating man of wry smiles, much wisdom and not a little mischief.
Ai Weiwei is sorry now - just as sorry as every American citizen living under a similarly merciless form of militarized government.
Top-drawer documentary about the art and activism of a Chinese artist who yearns for freedom.
As much as Never Sorry reveals about its central subject, it reveals just as much about the place where he lives, and the way demands for freedom find methods to limbo under oppression.
Doesn't mask its awe of the man, who comes off as a cross between a wise Buddha-figure and Santa Claus
As this sometimes haphazard documentary shows, Ai won't stop talking. Or blogging. Or tweeting.
A vital, informative wake-up call that will make you feel equally enraged and inspired.
The finale, as Ai's Twitter tirades lead to a serious human-rights breach, will make your blood boil.
You come away with an appreciation of the abstraction, scale and daring of Ai's art and, even more, a sense of the living man in his courage, humor and restlessness. It's an invigorating experience.
A sobering, cautionary tale.

One of the most engagingly powerful movies of the year almost completely on the strength of Ai's rumpled charisma and the confusion it creates in the bureaucratic mindset of the Chinese Communist Party.
Though he has paid the price, Ai is a pathfinder in this new phenomenon in tactical insurrection. Never Sorry is a new-style profile in 21st-century courage.

Ai admits that he's become "a brand for liberal thinking and individualism," though that's nothing to be ashamed of -- at this point, his Warholian talent for self-promotion may be the only thing keeping him alive.
Structurally ragged but engrossing documentary [about] a courageous provocateur with a gift for cleverly ridiculing a dangerous regime.
An excellent, revelatory new documentary. Weiwei proves a thoroughly compelling subject.
The story is enthralling, but it's not over, and there's no telling where it's going. Which makes what we see on screen all the more involving.
Klayman exploits the opportunity to follow a man at the eye of a cultural and political storm, although more detail on his creative process and private life would have welcome.
In terms of getting his message out to a wider audience, this film simply and effectively serves as part of the cause.
Affable and unpretentious, Ai comes across as a cagey operator whose candor is very appealing.
He is heroic.
It's likely to change the way you think about art and politics and the state of China today.

The boundaries between performance and protest are virtuosically, vitally fuddled in this stirring documentary chronicling three years in the life of Ai Weiwei, the outspoken Chinese artist and dissident.
Using archival footage dating back to Ai's adventures in the New York art world in his 20s, Klayman traces his evolution as a creator and as an activist.
The artist repudiated the repudiation. Art had, as art always should have, the last word.
Fascinating account of Weiwei's practice and politics that gives centre stage to his charismatic personality.
This is how a documentary portrait should be done.
Klayman's all-access, warts-and-all coverage of this artist's struggles with the State represents an extension of Ai's own ideals about transparency and freedom of expression.

[H]as a sense of the gloss to it: Ai is such a complex man, and he's operating in an environment that is alien to most Westerners, and so at every turn here, I wanted to get into much more depth than Klayman takes us to.
A powerful picture, yet, even more impressively, it treats art like a vessel for communication and meaningful exploration, not just as a stepping stone to cult fame.
His willingness to speak out despite severe consequences is inspiring, and his recent silence speaks almost as loudly as his work in calling attention to China's repressive tactics.
This essential, finely honed biographical portrait is jollied along by all the ironies and complexities of modern China.
Who doesn't hate it when critics say, "this is an important documentary you must see!" Well, Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry is a critically important documentary you need to see.
Well worth seeing.
Though we might wish for more insight or explanation, Klayman's film remains an incredible document of a courageous individual who the Chinese officials would prefer to make disappear.
A movie that somehow mixes apprehension for Ai with a feeling of warmth and, certainly, fun.
A lively, informative, funny and inspirational portrait of a courageous, charismatic, highly original man.
This riveting documentary deserves consideration for year-end awards. Klayman gained unprecedented access to this very photogenic man with a dynamic personality.
The film's recurring theme is of an artist on a perpetual hunt for transparency, in his country and abroad.
A powerful film that teaches us as much about ourselves as it does it's subject, "Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry," is a sure bet to be nominated for an Oscar come January 2013.
An unprecedented inside look at Chinese politics and a fascinating tour of modern art at the same time.
Klayman deserves a lot of credit for being in the right place at the right time with the right person. Ai is a treat to follow around, and his courage is clearly more than a pose.
Even if you don't like documentaries as a rule, I'm betting you'll like Ai Weiwei himself so much that you'll be glad you took the time to get to know him through this film.
... straightforward, entertaining and provocative documentary about the titular Chinese artist
A fascinating portrait of a modern artist and activist trying to make a difference within China's repressive political system.
Alison Klayman's remarkable film about China's leading 'digital dissident' fully illustrates the talents of a man who often does the opposite of what you'd expect.
The struggle for free speech in China is given sharp, sobering, disturbing voice through the struggles of cutting edge, digitally savvy, Twitter-loving artist Ai Weiwei.
A compelling documentary that explodes proper and stuffy notions of what a foreign intellectual dissident looks and sounds like.
Klayman never demonizes the authoritarian Chinese government, as her purpose seems to be to show how difficult it is to be a rebel in such a closed society as China.
The film is about the power and limits of art.
Ai Weiwei is such a laid back, calm and yet mischievous spirit that the film takes on a whole different, almost joyous tone.
To say Ai Weiwei is an interesting character is an understatement. He is an unconventional social activist and a thorn in the side of the authoritarian Chinese Communist Party.
Invigorating.

"Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry" is tightly focused on Ai, touching only superficially on the larger Chinese art scene and the political context in which he works. That said, the film is still highly informative.

Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry teaches us, if nothing else, that its subject will never stop speaking truth to power, whether in the form of a 140-character tweet or a large-scale piece of architecture that towers over the tiny men who try to keep him quiet.
Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry is both a perfect introduction to an endlessly intriguing individual, and a unveiling of sorts for fans who know the artist solely through the online arena.

Every art documentary has to look beyond the bubble of the artist. Ai Weiwei towers above the others, not just because of the artist's brilliant work...but because he keeps pushing art beyond its boundaries, out into the world.
If you are not in the slightest bit moved by it, then perhaps political and artistic apathy has sadly taken hold.
Broomfield frequently seems as willing as his subject to indulge in conspiracy theories and there often exists the queasy hunch that his interest in her feeds her sickness.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: As much a pointed and wise exploration of a documentarian's involvement in his subject matter as it is an angry indictment of the American judicial system.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: This is a chilling, extremely insightful documentary--not so much for what it tells us about Aileen Wuornos as for what it says about our society.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: A fascinating portrait of the woman, and a damning one of the society in which she lived.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: A profoundly disturbing film.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: It makes for a tabloid account, albeit a deliciously droll sidebar to The Selling Of A Serial Killer.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Told what to think, the viewer is distanced by film acknowleging its film-ness.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: The only reality here is that truth is slippery, and that's something Broomfield understands more than most documentary filmmakers working today.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Illuminates Wuornos' tragedy and eats into your mind.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Nick Broomfield's documentary, which chronicles the events that led up to the execution of Aileen Wuornos, is an absorbing film, partly because its subject exudes a scary charisma.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: She was guilty, no doubt, but as this immensely moving film makes clear, Aileen Wuornos was also heartbreakingly human.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: As gripping and suspenseful as anything Hollywood is capable of turning out.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Might have been a good film, except that Broomfield had the inside track. His films are, ultimately, always about the making of his films.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: An eloquent case against the death penalty, especially when imposed on the mentally incompetent.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Broomfield is mostly just shooting from the hip and missing as much as he scores
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: The filmmaker's ego and ethics aside, there's no denying the power of Wuornos' behavior here.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Broomfield's film is typically self-aggrandizing but filled with unsettling moments.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: The director ... makes a compelling argument that Wuornos never got a fair deal from the legal system and that she should have been spared death because of insanity.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Except for the sermonizing, altogether a deeper, more interesting movie than Monster.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Broomfield's voiceover commentary sounds like a bad Robin Leach impression at times, but his fascinating interviews with the real Wuornos elicit sympathy as well as a strong case of the heebie-jeebies.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: [Broomfield] makes an entertaining and at times even compelling argument, whatever his topic.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Even if she skirts the big questions, Wuornos is a riveting presence -- affable and articulate one minute, twitchy and petulant the next.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Marked by Broomfield's same stentorian, recurrently officious narration... but still a sharp, affecting portrait of monstrous underclass miasma.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: An essential viewing companion to its dramatic narrative counterpart.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer should be seen, probably before Monster. Maybe instead of Monster.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: It's a far more gripping documentary than Broomfield's 1992 Wuornos film.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: If you have the stomach for it, this engrossing documentary sheds additional light on a controversial figure whose case continues to incite debate.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Wuornos became, by the old standards of stark morality, evil, but was undeniably a classic victim and victimizer. Thanks to Broomfield and others, she is a sleepless night that endures.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Digs into the soul of this abused child, who never got the treatment she needed. Her eyes, radiating madness, will haunt your dreams.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Though one can question the movie's quality as a documentary ... Aileen raises such troubling issues that it stays, hellishly, in your mind.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Her intense denial is fascinating, and extremely sad, to watch.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: No one should have to endure the life that Aileen Wuornos led, and we leave the movie believing that if someone, somehow, had been able to help that little girl, her seven victims would never have died.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: It does ... make a powerful argument against capital punishment, no matter which side of the debate you happen to take.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: A valuable and insightful contribution to the mountain of Aileen Wuornos speculation and documentation.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: [T]his movie literally gave me the chills.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Engrossing, educational, amusing and disturbing.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Provides an opportunity to study one of history's supposed anomalies: a female serial killer.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Does afford a real-life view of Wuornos during the days of her final appeal and her ultimate date with death.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Broomfield is too fond of himself by half, and tilts the movie too much toward his personal objections to the death penalty.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Just as Broomfield's latest points a harsh light on those who profited from her death, so too does he stray into their territory, giving a broken woman one final humiliation.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Broomfield, who keeps himself in the frame as he investigates, tells the story with the panache of a pulp true-crime author.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: As much about the culture that produces and fears, consumes and condemns, an Aileen Wuornos as it is about Aileen Wuornos.

review_content: The filmmaker misses too many opportunities by focusing too much on himself.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Even as Broomfield inserts himself (as usual) into the narrative, Wuornos grabs the spotlight with all of her wild-eyed fury.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: It's clear Theron didn't so much resemble [Wuornos] as she did channel her deeply tormented soul, in a way that Broomfield never manages to do.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: While I prefer more even-handed approaches to documentary film, there’s no denying the power of the footage, particularly that featuring [Aileen] Wuornos.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: This compassionate documentary should be of strong interest to viewers of the previous Wuornos film or the current Monster.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Though unpleasant to watch, Life and Death of a Serial Killer presents a portrait of evil, betrayal and banality that's almost impossible to take your eyes off of.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Not even Charlize Theron's lauded portrayal of the accused can compete with the captivating genuine article, whose calculated professions of remorse barely conceal her festering rage at a lifetime of mistreatment.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: A haunting exploration of a ruined and wasted life.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: [Broomfield's] least exploitative, most personal work to date
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Aileen is, if anything, a scathing indictment against the death penalty and its proponents, keeping with the concept that all life is precious.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: The film stands quite chillingly as a final statement from a woman trying to fight her own commodification.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Broomfield's misplaced exasperation is almost poignant.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: Alm de investigar com maior profundidade as origens da violncia de Aileen, o documentrio ainda comprova a perfeio da performance de Charlize Theron em Monster.

review_content: The most intense depiction of the complicated relationship between documentary filmmaker and subject of all time.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: A deeply fascinating follow-up because of how much of Wuornos' story is changed from one film to the next, as well as for its moving consideration of the complex and often unbalanced relationship between documentarian and subject.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer

review_content: A damning portrait of cold-hearted greed.

review_content: Though undermining and ignoring some facts about the serial killer, Broomfield's docu is entertaining and it certainly capture the media frenzy (boderline zoo) and bizarre participants in this perculiar case. Make sure to watch the follow-up.

review_content: Broomfield ends up exploring a world that cares more about money and deals than about life and death.
movie_title: Aileen Wuornos - The Selling of a Serial Killer

review_content: Aileen Wuornos is raw, fascinating and less than ideally organized. But as a portrait of a world obsessed with cashing in on tragedy, it couldn't be more timely.
movie_title: Aileen Wuornos - The Selling of a Serial Killer

review_content: I wouldn't exactly call Air Guitar Nation the next important documentary, but as a colorful look at an admittedly goofy activity, the flick's a pleasant little winner.
A wildly foolish flick that takes the best elements of stand-up comedy and mixes them with good, old-fashioned rock 'n' roll.
the film will be remembered for the overall sense of camaraderie overcoming competition, fraternity trumping rivalry, and the discovery of graciousness in victory and defeat
Alexandra Lipsitz's often hilarious documentary (with almost everyone in on the joke) won the audience award at SXSW and is spawning a cult following that could snowball in release.
Nary a dull lick in the entire 80 minutes.
Air Guitar Nation is a wonderfully wild ride of a documentary, and the greatest trick of the picture is found in how it makes the audience succumb to the power of the sport.
Air Guitar Nation plays less like a feature-length documentary than it does a poorly thrown together behind-the-scenes supplement to the real thing.
It's never clear from one moment to the next what is a joke and what is deadly earnest, until the two concepts finally merge into a sort of Buddhist singularity.
Fascinating? Absolutely.
As dumb as the idea of grown men dressing up and pretending to play guitar may be, there's no arguing that some of these grown men do so with a truly awesome degree of energy and flair.
Irresistible.
It's no small feat to film a documentary like this with the right balance of reverence for the craft of air guitar and good, old-fashioned shooting at an easy target, but Lipsitz pulls it off.
Although Air Guitar Nation is a documentary, Lipsitz stumbled across a couple of compelling characters in Jung and Crane, who are anything but n'air-do-wells.
There are enough endearing characters and charming trash talk to keep what is essentially a one-note joke running toward the spastic crescendo with alacrity.
The movie's wild performances and droll humor are tough to resist.
Alexandra Lipsitz believes that air-guitar competitions are worth a whole feature-length movie. She's wrong, of course. But the fun lasts longer than you might think.
Air Guitar Nation does a fine job of bottling prelapsarian exuberance.

The documentary is very well paced, beginning with a montage of just what one would presume to be the typical air guitar of a drunken concert goer and progressing into a film chronicling something like showmanship.
It's hard not to grin and admit that, yes, this is almost an art form.
It's one of the charms of Air Guitar Nation that much of it plays like a mockumentary in which you're not quite sure who's pulling your leg. But it's real, even if the guitars are not.
Director Alexandra Lipsitz doesn't do much more than chronicle the noise, but it's intermittently fun stuff.
This is all charming and hilariously real.

The Finns take the whole thing pretty seriously, noting that if you hold an air guitar, it's impossible to simultaneously hold a gun or rifle. (I'm sure some hombre in a Peckinpah movie would be able to pull it off.)
It makes me what to pick up an air guitar and rock out.

A favorite on the film festival circuit, Alexandra Lipsitz's exuberantly funny documentary follows the triumphant path of an American air guitarist as he rises from U.S. East Coast champ to the top rankings of the international air guitar festival.
Air Guitar Nation will appeal to genuine musicians and those who play their fake guitars behind closed doors.
[A] jolly, oddly compelling and genuinely suspenseful documentary.
The film is a lovingly hilarious portrait of a bizarre and endearing pastime.
The suggestion is that C-Diddy can be seen as a sort of ambassador for the 'make air, not war' sentiment. Why not? Even as real ambassadors go, we could do worse.
This very funny film should get audiences strumming along on their own air guitars and flashing devil horns in support of these masters of mock rock.
When one character cheerfully announces he wants to "out-weird the world," we want to let him know we're right there for him.

There are occasional moments of wisdom, drama and emotion, but we never quite forget the blunt confession of one of the founders of the world championship, who admits that the whole thing began as a joke. Psst, buddy: it still is.
That the event is not only taken seriously by its contestants, but is also surprisingly devoid of irony, makes Air Guitar Nation excellently enjoyable.
It's a limited movie, from the musical palette the performers choose, to the number of players the movie spends time with.

In this pitch-perfect documentary about the very real rise of air guitar competition in the United States, and two of its top performers, stony thoughts will arise as to whether one is suddenly trapped inside a satire that got wrapped in a reality.

The film's action footage -- lots of men and women thrashing around with a theoretical Fender in hand -- gets pretty tedious after a while. There is only so much self-inflicted embarrassment one can bear watching.
[Some] may be taken aback by the exhibition of sheer ego in what is clearly a form of replacement therapy for those whose ambitions exceed their talents.

"Air Guitar Nation" does deliver the goods, with some extremely funny scenes and some honest-to-goodness rocking concert footage. Although I fear that the existence of "Nation" has nudged us that much closer to a karaoke documentary.
As "Seinfeld" proved, shows about nothing can be a lot of fun.
For every dork who has stood before the home stereo speakers and banged away on an invisible instrument, here at last is validation.
Sure, there is an infectious goofiness in watching a grown man in a red robe and Hello Kitty breastplate rock out on an imaginary ax. But the gag is spread pretty thin.
a fun enough goof to give it 90 minutes of your time as a feature film.
Somehow, after most of the other 2007 movies have faded from memory, I have a feeling that I will still remember the passion and commitment of the people I met in Air Guitar Nation.

Air Guitar Nation is a very well-made film and it tells its story at a quick, even pace, but you really need to suspend your disbelief if you're going to allow this film to fully wrap you in its charms.
When a documentary compels you to care about something that you didn't think you had any interest in, well... that rocks!
A genuinely funny and absorbing documentary.
A delightfully surreal look at a bizarre performance art.
Hugely entertaining, frequently hilarious documentary with colourful, warm-hearted characters and an infectious energy that'll send you bouncing out of the cinema with a goofy grin on your face.
This raucously entertaining documentary about one of the silliest competitions on the planet actually has a serious message about the power of "airness" to change the world. Well, maybe.
There must be better, more useful ways of amusing themselves but obviously none which would allow them to strut the stage to the plaudits of a baying crowd like latter-day rock stars.
Very funny.
Like most guitar solos, the film doesn't quite know when to quit.
Originality 0.9, Presentation 2.3 and Silliness 5.2.
Despite the film's admirable brevity it's still hard to maintain a wry ironic grin for a full 81 minutes.
While quite possibly the stupidest thing you've ever seen in your life, this documentary exploring the world of air guitar enthusiasts is a riot from start to finish.
A gloriously insane journey into the weirder reaches of rock, Air Guitar Nation is a funny, funky and oddly moving burst of lively factual entertainment.
Shot in a raw, grungy style that lends the film a degree of authenticity, AGN is a riff-roaring experience that rarely hits a bum note.
you will be entertained even if, in rock'n' roll terms, it's less satanic metal than cutesy chart pop.
A nuts-and-bolts document of the annual Air Guitar World Championships which take place in the rural outpost of Oulu in Finland.
When a documentary is as entertaining as Air Guitar Nation, you have to ask if you really need it to have redeeming social value or to advance the art form in any way.
Put aside all of your preconceptions of air guitar as a hobby of shamelessly untalented wanna-be guitar players, and step into the world of competitive air guitar.
It isn't so much the battle of the one-man-bands that is so compelling, as the journey itself, as sublime as it is ridiculous.
Just when you thought there weren't any more reasons to hate America.

A cheeky, somewhat suspect documentary on the battles between an icon of stoner comedy and the Feds, a/k/a Tommy Chong serves up a biased account of Chong's arrest and incarceration for manufacturing drug paraphernalia.
First-time filmmaker Josh Gilbert, whose skills behind the camera are rudimentary, might be a bit too close to his subject to do disinterested viewers justice.
The movie's value varies according to how much of the story you already know.
A surprisingly clear-eyed, sober account of what it's liked to be embraced by a culture, while loathed by the Powers That Be.
Its dramatic thinness doesn't dilute its simultaneously ridiculous and terrifying portrait of federal prosecution run amok.
Josh Gilbert's smoothly produced documentary a/k/a Tommy Chong should leave even Nancy Reagan aghast at the unfair trials of comedian Tommy Chong.
This genial doc sprinkles Reagan and Nixon soundbites over its vintage stash of C&C clips for a suitably fuzzy squint at America from '69 to the buzzkill present.
It is also a portrait of resilience: Chong does his time (nine months) and has the last laugh, emerging as a born-again activist-survivor of the culture wars.
Josh Gilbert's film tells the depressing, often ridiculous and generally enraging story of how and why Tommy Chong ended up doing time in a minimum-security prison.
How the feds inadver tently resurrected the performing career of stoner comic Tommy Chong by busting him is the ironic subtext of Josh Gilbert's one-sided documentary a/k/a Tommy Chong.
should have gone for more
What could have been either a scathing critique of the drug war or an intimate portrait of a stoner facing mortality instead comes off as a fawning infomercial for its subject.
Apparently granted unlimited access to Chong's personal archives, Gilbert digs up some great footage and photos from his early years as well his '70s heyday.
Even those unimpressed with [Cheech and Chong's] genially lowbrow work will be intrigued by the political tenor of this portrait.
This is an important propaganda film. After all, Gilbert has all the facts in hand and presents it halfway decently.
This isn't a great piece of nonfiction filmmaking, but it has its moments.
What comes across is Chong's innate elegance and intelligence, two qualities often missing from his trademark comedic work.
A very scary documentary illustrating the carte blanche accorded Big Brother by the Patriot Act

Rather than some rambling, pro-pot film, this flick actually does a pretty good job of documenting the issues surrounding Chong's arrest, and the obvious intention by the Ashcroft justice department to bring down an icon of the debauched 70s.

Josh Gilbert's curt documentary about the arrest and conviction of comedian and former bong-maker Tommy Chong reveals the federal sting operation that put Tommy Chong in a state penitentiary for nine months for shipping glass bongs to Pennsylvania.
...funny/scary account of the persecution of another of Lenny's disciples.
If you've ever played chess, you'll appreciate the dedication that the film's blind protagonist devote to the only sport that sharpens the brain rather than destroys it.
Three visually impaired teenage boys from India who play chess at the championship level are the subject of this slow-moving yet soulful documentary.
As with many stories about children involved in a competitive activity, "Algorithms" is partly a portrait of grown-up hopes channeled through kids.
But the result is simply a literal draining of additional color from an already pallid piece of work that does little justice to the incredible struggles of these exceptional young men.
...while these disparate parts are compelling on a surface level, Algorithms is unable to cohere into a decent, coherent, and consistently paced whole.
An object lesson in how a remarkable subject can be turned into a less remarkable film.

"Algorithms" is a completely unique film, unlike any other documentary you'll see this year, both for its content and its form. But it is also a deeply absorbing, timeless, universal tale with themes anyone can find inspiration in.
Shot - a little obviously - in black and white, Ian McDonald's film is otherwise a winning documentary that develops into a story as intense and focused as his subjects.
Shot in black and white, and featuring lots of close-ups of fingers reading the chess pieces like braille, the film echoes the meditative pacing of the game.
It's rare to see such transcendence in a film. And that's exactly why this should be watched and cherished by every movie buff out there.
The narrative moves seamlessly between the games and competitions to the boys' homes, neighbourhoods and cities. When it comes to the sport itself, the film plants you on the 64 squares.
Visually arresting as it is, the pic stands out mainly for its subject matter, the first documentary on blind chess, even though it fits snugly within the sub-genre of underdog stories.
Algorithms makes me wish I could play the game. More importantly, it demonstrates that, just like chess is about the mind, so is (dis)ability.
Like many IMAX films, it's worth a look for the razzle-dazzle photography, but don't expect much in the way of serious science.
With Imax-sized ambitions, James Cameron is the ideal tour guide for these fascinating expeditions.
Cameron and his crew have captured mesmerizing footage.

It's good that a kid, and maybe even an adult, may want to 'touch' one of the so-called aliens thrust out for our inspection. But more important, a kid, and maybe even an adult, may want to become a human scientist.
Last time we checked, 'Cool' wasn't in the official scientist-jargon handbook... go see this to be entertained rather than to be educated.
A grandiose hybrid of undersea documentary and outer-space fantasy.
The 48-minute spellbinder will make your jaw drop with awe. And, like the best documentaries, it will also make you think.
A major treat for the eyes.
Monsters, egotistical directors, special effects -- yeah, this isn't exactly the Scientific American. But many of the sights in Aliens of the Deep are spectacular.
We go 'ooh' and 'aaah' with these guys and gals.
Aliens of the Deep has a few moments of awe but its overall message is utilitarian, using ocean exploration as a stepping stone to outer space adventures.
Puts some of these incredible creatures right in our laps. And we don't even need to travel hundreds of light years to see them.
definitely worth the price of admission -- even if you have to wear the stupid glasses
It's a fascinating, kid-friendly journey, - some clunky dialogue and the injection of Hollywood-style hypothesizing about what Europa's aliens might look like.
The crew ooos and aahs and talks like so many valley girls ("awesome," "freaky," etc.), leaving the viewer hungry for some more substantive science to back up the visuals.
You'll see some strange, gentle wonders in Aliens of the Deep.
Though only 48 minutes long and the 3-D effects are sometimes stunning, it has substantial passages that are curiously dull...can't hold a candle to Cameron's other 'Aliens.'
Visually, this is another leap for 3D and robotic cameras.
Cameron's extrapolation of undersea exploration into the realm of outer space amounts to little more than atomic age fiction for the layperson.
Cameron is no longer content to merely show what's down there. Aliens of the Deep also speculates about what might be up there. Way up there in outer space.
In the end, you have to give Cameron points for putting his financial muscle behind scientific expeditions rather than, say, lavish parties.
An educational and thoroughly entertaining documentary that's in the Everest class of great IMAX movies.
An adventure that -- right up until the end -- is a magnificent journey of scientific discovery and exploration.
Wow! Aliens! No, I mean really, creatures like nothing you've ever seen before...
Cameron's showmanship and his on-screen appearances make his documentaries far livelier than your usual IMAX nature documentary, and this one is no exception.
We're treated to more intramural banter and golly-gee chatter among the crew than we can use, and are not given enough scientific information.
Less focused thematically than its predecessor, the Titanic film Ghosts of the Abyss, Aliens of the Deep is nonetheless a visually enthralling undersea travelogue.

Now, not much gets answered, and some of the conclusions take a Hollywood imagination to go there, but it's sure fun to ride shotgun and see Cameron play with his expensive toys -- all in the name of research.
Beyond a doubt the biggest movie ever made about shrimp, Aliens of the Deep is a technical marvel that still manages to fall somewhere severely south of marvelous.
Both dazzling underwater ballet and a welcome salvo for clarity in the current backlash against evolution.
Not a scientific documentary so much as a journey to an alien world, and basically what we want to do is peer out the portholes along with the explorers.
One sign of a successful IMAX outing is how it makes you believe you are there in every frame, and this one does.
[Though] he's like the Joe Garagiola of the deep...Cameron's unadvisable whims are excusable: as a coffee table book, Aliens of the Deep is a beaut.

When the cameras focus on the weird geography and strange beings of the ocean depths and on the expressive reactions of those observing it all through the walls of their vessels, they capture a wonder you feel privileged to behold.
Though the experience is mind-boggling, it can also spark blurry optical overload.
Often thrilling.
It's fantastic stuff.
Most of us will never have the good fortune to see these sights in their natural habitats, but the marvelous 3-D imagery reveals them gloriously.
... captures not only the majesty of the brinier depths - but also the fascination therein that keeps luring Cameron back to the ocean.
The first two-thirds of Aliens of the Deep offer a fascinating peek into earth's mysteries.
It is useful to be reminded every once in a while that there's a whole universe of things we don't know, and that their discovery is exciting.
Much of the allure of the film comes from Cameron's easygoing, rather unscientific approach to the project.
It presents complex ideas simply with amazing visuals to wow those from eight to eighty.

Here we know only that Cameron and his bright-eyed young scientists (who take turns narrating) are heading to the deeper parts of the Atlantic and Pacific to observe the environment and life-forms down there.
It's visually stunning, but [James Cameron] can't resist going slightly too far with its premise.
It is a lot more like being there than just watching pictures taken by someone who was there.
The experience is so immediate and immersive that you actually feel as if you are swimming with the krill.
There are impressive rock formations and many other fine things to see, along with an interesting science lesson.
Some great shots of some odd (alien) deep sea fish and a good tie into space exploration, but other than that, the 3D isn't that great and reaction shots go too long.
A master showman's large-format documentary, a movie with great images, great special effects and the sheen of Hollywood often missing in these museum or science-center movies.
[Cameron] speculates that the ocean's depths contain mysterious life unlike anything else on Earth.
I want the old James Cameron back.
The final shot, in particular, is awesome, and confirms that the sooner Cameron gets back to making proper movies, instead of Boys' Own diversions, the better.

That IMAX 3-D cameras have plunged so deep to record an often bizarre array of sea creatures undoubtedly delivers a certain 'wow' factor, but the accompanying commentary is heavier on breathless excitement than solid fact.
Even if these plants and animals did not exist, we may have already invented them, courtesy of those sci fi special effects magicians working overtime for the past decades.
Once you get used to the "awesome" and "wow"-heavy dialogue, James Cameron's excursion into both 3-D technology and deep ocean trenches delivers some fascinating footage.
The far more interesting stuff is back here at the bottom of the sea.
It's not usual for documentaries to ingest the sci-fi genre, but in this case it's an eye pleasing and mind boggling excursion, beautifully realised and seamlessly integrated into the film.
A fascinating science lesson for anyone interested in either deep-sea -- or outer space -- exploration.
Yes, the work they're doing is mind-boggling and important, but sometimes the images alone are more than capable of speaking for themselves.
Docu about underwater creatures has stunning visuals.
Another piece of essential viewing for outsiders trying to understand life in the Middle East.
An interesting, if not entirely successful, adaptation of an excellent book.
Amos Gitai's acidly comic study of life in a flimsy Tel Aviv apartment complex is a sour urban mosaic whose seedy characters, try as they might, can't get out of one another's faces.
Gitai ... records the comings and goings with a keen eye.
Extremely well-acted and generally absorbing.
None of the characters or situations truly manages to hold our attention, though there are some arresting moments.
Gita's portrait of self-destructive lives is certainly honest, but his direction is suffocating.

The story and even the characters turn out to be less interesting than the overview it gives us of the way Israelis live now, its portrait of a dislocated society where despair rumbles beneath the surface of everyday life.
For non-Israeli audiences, Alila is an alternately illuminating and confounding glimpse into seldom-seen aspects of the country.

Though absorbing enough, Alila must be counted a noble failure, if only because its efforts to follow the screwed-up lives of 12 hapless souls in a seedy Tel Aviv apartment building finally add up more to mere mimicry than commentary.
It's a bit of a mess.
For all its flaws, Alila is an interesting social issue film.
It's too acerbic to be funny and too detached to be really moving.
...Gitai has populated the story with one unlikable character after another, making it impossible for the viewer to connect with anything on screen.
Suggesting that the strain of the Arab conflict has gotten to the Israelis and that peace might only be a pipe dream.
Gitai delivers an amazing film every bit as satisfying as his masterpiece Kippur (2001).
An achingly comprehensive poker-praising documentary that unfolds in rather scattershot form, yet still remains more or less entertaining enough to engage non-players.
Celebrating the worldwide poker renaissance, it's intriguing in the way it delineates another way to chase the American Dream.
The film has a shambling charm that actively disputes an unspoken notion that a documentary must be well-structured in order to effectively land its points.
Instead of sustaining a significant cultural story, at almost two hours, All In feels like an energetic but overlong highlight reel.
Frankly, it could have used a touch more disrepute.
So padded with cheerleading that it doesn't have time for a serious exploration of poker's place in the broader culture or the consequences of its rapid rise and global reach.
Douglas Tirola's pic seems a bit late for the poker craze, and at any rate will be preaching largely to the converted.

Engrossing documentary on the multi-billion-dollar poker industry gets a little too rhapsodic about the game as a metaphor for life and slips into advocacy for online poker, all while offering a revealing, wide-ranging look at a subculture.
"All In" lays down some interesting hands but sometimes can't raise the stakes, though "Rounders" star Matt Damon lends a bit of celeb flash.
Amusing and informative (and hyperbolic) as it is, "All In: The Poker Movie" is a documentary whose intended audience is unclear.
[An] energetic, if overly worshipful documentary.
Follow the film-maker. Let him lead you by the nose. Lanthimos knows exactly where he's going.
The cumulative force of the screenplay and Yorgos Mavropsaridis' editing is not as hypnotic as in Dogtooth, perhaps in part because those familiar with Lanthimos' m.o. will know what to expect.
It simply demands to be stared at, in awe or incomprehension.
Feels like a pale shadow of its predecessor.

An overly elaborate riddle
The premise is fetching and feels like a mystery, particularly as the film orchestrates its story to make the work of the Alps group seem like a kind of heist.

Feels very much like a companion piece to Dogtooth; albeit a subtler, less confronting, and also less powerful one. How could it possibly compare? But Alps does have one trump card; a profoundly sad beating heart.
A barely accessible look at the permeability of identity recommended as a reflection of the director's vivid imagination.
ALPS is a real mind trip with strong acting, and it leaves you to wonder what Lanthimos and Filippou will do next.
Lanthimos' film, with its emphasis on death deferred, holds the chilly fascination of a gaping skull.

Both a companion piece to and in many ways a reversal of Dogtooth, it builds on that film's surreally terse style and notions of communication and identity without diluting its singularity or concentration
Puzzling and provocative, Alps has a lingering power and an effect that is thrillingly difficult to define.
A comedy of pained laughter, Alps confirms the certitude of our darkest hours: The dead are the lucky ones.
Oblique connections are the threads that hold this film together, as Mr. Lanthimos moves from one somber, deliberate scene to the next.
An impressively taut absurdist drama that's deliberate in its exploration of the value and limits of compassion.
There's no sense of how this service ever works, and only a scant indication of the miseries from which Papoulia is trying to escape by assuming a new identity.
The tone is one of deadpan discombobulation, a world turned 45 degrees to the left but presented with a clear, dry perspective.
The movie focuses tightly and obviously on role playing, but the most unsettling observations concern how fragile it all is - our health, our minds, our denial of death.
Lanthimos continually keeps you guessing about both the procedural and emotional logic at work in "Alps," and his actors are with him every step of the way.
After the failure of his insufferable last film "Dogtooth," Greek auteur Yorgos Lanthimos refines his minimalist approach to absurdist satire.
This cinematic experience was weirdly fascinating.
A strange story. A strange world. And strange characters doing even stranger things.
...registers less as a drama than as a filmed scientific experiment.
The movie contains some of the same elements that made [Dogtooth] so startling but they tend to float around rather than coalesce into a singular perspective.
Lanthimos' vision still compels and challenges, but Alps offers a big idea in place of a better movie.
A film peculiar beyond all understanding, based on a premise that begs belief.
The film takes some deciphering, but once a viewer cracks its code "Alps" opens up into something expansive and rich.
Helps make the case that Lanthimos might be a worthy, more entomological successor to Luis Buuel.
An hour and a half of darkening absurdism.
Absurdly amusing (in places), rigorously directed, and more interesting on an intellectual level than an emotional one.
Lanthimos delivers another heady dose of weirdness. Loopier than a frog sandwich but rather wonderful.
The reality it takes place in is heightened just enough to make the concept feel ironic, but then all attempt at genuine sentiment subsequently falls flat.
Lanthimos is such a distinctive film-maker and nothing he does is without interest - but this is a misfire.
The movie's morbidly funny once you get the hang of it, and climaxes deftly, but for too long Lanthimos feels like he's stalling for no especial purpose.
Requires multiple viewings to pick this one apart.
From the Greek filmmakers behind the acclaimed anti-thriller Dogtooth, this fiendishly inventive drama is just as complex and telling.
What does it mean?
It's hard to see what, if anything, Lanthimos is saying about modern Greece. And without that clear focus, the film feels a bit off-piste.
Emphatically weird, watchable and niche.
In fact, you probably shouldn't be reading this review if you have an interest in seeing the film.
It will certainly keep you interested, but the ending lacks the strength to make it work completely. [Full review in Spanish]
Giorgos Lanthimos﻿' "Alps" is a gimmick brought to life, a conceptual idea of a social situation filmed with automatons and containing but an illustration of a concept.
Lanthimos's film Dogtooth disturbed and impressed a lot of people, and I doubt his new film ALPS will receive a different reaction.
This remarkably enjoyable film undoubtedly demands a second viewing -- and most importantly, proves that Lanthimos isn't just a one-hit wonder.
The acting is excellent throughout, each performer managing to play up the comic aspects with a new definition of deadpan.
As predictably intolerable as one might've anticipated...
There's not enough about the conflicts between Paul and those who controlled his records but this is a fan-like yet not too oleaginous tribute.

review_content: There's no inch of this movie that's boring.
